title: Which is false: Oxaliplatin or fluoropyrimidine? An analysis of patients with KRAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer treated with first-line epidermal growth factor receptor monoclonal antibody
abstract: This meta-analysis was performed to determine whether the addition of monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) to oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy treatment improves efficacy in KRAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC), and whether infusional 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) and oxaliplatin is a preferred combination for EGFR mAbs. Oxaliplatin (including treatment), EGFR mAbs, first-line treatment, KRAS wild-type, and mCRC were used as key words. The PRIME, OPUS, COIN, and NORDIC VII trials were identified by two independent authors. Time-to-event outcomes of overall survival (OS) and progression-free survival (PFS) were analyzed using HRs (hazard ratios) with fixed effect, and response rate (RR) using odd ratios (OR) with fixed effect. A total of 1767 patients who were KRAS wild-type were included in this meta-analysis, with 866 patients in the mAbs and chemotherapy combination group and 901 patients in the chemotherapy alone group. The addition of mAbs to oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy in patients with KRAS wild-type mCRC as first-line treatment resulted in significant improvements in PFS (HR = 0.88; 95% confidence interval (CI), 0.79-0.99; P = 0.03) and response rate (RR) (OR = 1.38; 95% CI, 1.14-1.66; P = 0.009) compared with chemotherapy alone, but the difference in OS was not significant (HR = 0.96; 95% CI, 0.85-1.08; P = 0.48). However, the differences in OS and PFS were not significant when mAbs were added to bolus 5-FU or capecitabine-based regimens compared with chemotherapy alone, whereas PFS improved with an infusional 5-FU and oxaliplatin combination (P = 0.06; PFS, HR = 0.76; 95% CI, 0.65-0.86; P = 0.0002), and even OS was marginally significant, which was consistent with the subgroup analysis of cetuximab and panitumumab. EGFR mAbs combined with oxaliplatin and an infusional 5-FU regimen was associated with significantly improved RR, PFS and OS as first-line treatment in KRAS wild-type mCRC.

motivations: There is a need to determine whether adding epidermal growth factor receptor monoclonal antibodies to oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy improves efficacy in KRAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.
The optimal combination of chemotherapy and monoclonal antibodies for treating metastatic colorectal cancer is unclear.
objectives: Evaluate the efficacy of adding epidermal growth factor receptor monoclonal antibodies to oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy in KRAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.
Determine whether infusional 5-fluorouracil and oxaliplatin is a preferred combination for epidermal growth factor receptor monoclonal antibodies.
methods: Conduct a meta-analysis of existing trials, including PRIME, OPUS, COIN, and NORDIC VII.
Analyze time-to-event outcomes of overall survival and progression-free survival using hazard ratios with fixed effect.
Analyze response rate using odd ratios with fixed effect.
results: The addition of monoclonal antibodies to oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy improves progression-free survival and response rate in KRAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

Infusional 5-fluorouracil and oxaliplatin is a preferred combination for epidermal growth factor receptor monoclonal antibodies, associated with improved response rate, progression-free survival, and overall survival.
llama_json.research_subject: Efficacy of epidermal growth factor receptor monoclonal antibodies with oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy in KRAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer

motivations: There is uncertainty about the efficacy of adding monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) to oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy in treating KRAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).
The optimal combination of chemotherapy drugs to use with EGFR mAbs for this type of cancer is unclear.
objectives: Determine whether the addition of EGFR mAbs to oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy improves efficacy in KRAS wild-type mCRC.
Assess whether infusional 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) and oxaliplatin is a preferred combination for EGFR mAbs.
methods: Perform a meta-analysis of trials using key words related to the research question.

Analyze time-to-event outcomes of overall survival (OS) and progression-free survival (PFS) using hazard ratios (HRs) with fixed effect, and response rate (RR) using odd ratios (OR) with fixed effect.
results: The addition of mAbs to oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy in patients with KRAS wild-type mCRC as first-line treatment resulted in significant improvements in PFS and RR compared with chemotherapy alone.
The differences in OS and PFS were not significant when mAbs were added to bolus 5-FU or capecitabine-based regimens compared with chemotherapy alone.
PFS improved with an infusional 5-FU and oxaliplatin combination, and even OS was marginally significant.
openai_json.research_subject: Efficacy of adding EGFR mAbs to oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy in treating KRAS wild-type mCRC

motivations: The optimal combination of EGFR monoclonal antibodies with chemotherapy for KRAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer remains unclear.
There is uncertainty about whether oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy benefits from the addition of EGFR monoclonal antibodies and which fluoropyrimidine formulation is most effective.
objectives: Determine whether adding EGFR monoclonal antibodies to oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy improves efficacy in KRAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.
Evaluate whether infusional 5-fluorouracil combined with oxaliplatin is the preferred chemotherapy backbone for EGFR monoclonal antibodies.
methods: Conducted a meta-analysis of four randomized controlled trials (PRIME, OPUS, COIN, and NORDIC VII) comparing EGFR monoclonal antibodies plus chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone.
Analyzed time-to-event outcomes using hazard ratios with fixed effect models and response rates using odds ratios with fixed effect models.
results: Addition of EGFR monoclonal antibodies to oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy significantly improved progression-free survival and response rate but not overall survival in KRAS wild-type patients.
The combination of EGFR monoclonal antibodies with infusional 5-fluorouracil and oxaliplatin showed superior outcomes compared to combinations with bolus 5-fluorouracil or capecitabine.
anthropic_json.research_subject: Efficacy of EGFR monoclonal antibodies combined with different chemotherapy regimens in KRAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer
